results.title: Portraits: people with epilepsy
results.creator_credit: Samantha Shepherd, Donna Graham and Epilepsy Queensland
results.brief_description: Five people from different walks of life talk about their experience with epilepsy. Hugo Weaving tells of how it affects/doesn’t affect his work as an actor. Retiree Jean reflects on her life as an epileptic mother. Chef Ian addresses how he adapts his work in a stressful job to accommodate his condition. Uni student Sally talks about what it was like to study, then travel overseas, and primary school teacher Amanda explains how her students cope in the classroom. The five talk candidly about their achievements and how epilepsy has affected their lives. Funded by the Health Advancement Branch of Queensland Health and produced for Epilepsy Queensland.

results.title: Pork on the farm: killing, curing and canning
results.brief_description: Details the best methods for raising pigs for home use (as distinct from marketing them) are given; correct slaughtering methods are shown; the general principles which give nest results in cutting up pork are demonstrated; and detailed descriptions of carious ways of curing pork.

results.title: Pooling around
results.creator_credit: Paul Galan and Continental Oil Company
results.brief_description: Looks at a van pool commuter program established by the American firm Conoco. With the aim of energy conservation, employees commute to work in a van. Shows the beneficial aspects for the company and the employees.

results.title: Pond animals
results.brief_description: Demonstrates methods of collecting pond animals, both microscopic and macroscopic, and encourages children to study pond life for themselves. A newt, stickleback and wil-i-gig beetle are caught and then in jars to the laboratory to be examined. Other animals seen are the water scorpion, Great Pond Snail, Water Boatmen, Daphnia and others. A drop of pond water is also studied under the microscope.

results.title: Poetry for me
results.brief_description: An original method of presenting children’s poetry. Introduces the fundamental ideas of rhythm, imagery, and word sounds. Shows that poetry is wonderfully descriptive, using all the aspects of language to communicate meaning with feeling. Develops the idea that poetry stimulates a greater appreciation of surroundings.

results.title: Poetry for fun: trulier coolier
results.brief_description: This film features eight poems, chosen by children and dealing with what children do, what they think about, and how they feel about their world. Included are animated cartoons, giant puppets, creative photography and music. Suitable for lower and upper primary levels.
